questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following best describes an amyloid?
questions.explanation:
Amyloid can be best described as a proteoglycan. Amyloidosis refers to the extracellular deposition of fibrillar proteins. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits 
bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans (heparan sulfate and dermatan 
sulfate), and plasma proteins (serum amyloid P component). The abundant charged sugar groups in these adsorbed proteins give the deposits staining 
characteristics that resemble starch (amylose). Therefore, these deposits are called amyloid. Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

questions.question:
Question 2: In a patient with reactive systemic amyloidosis, which of the following proteins are likely to 
get deposited in the tissues?
questions.explanation:
There is the deposition of AA proteins in reactive systemic amyloidosis (secondary amyloidosis). In inflammatory states, there is a release of IL-1 and IL-6, which act on the liver cells. The liver 
increases the production of SAA (serum amyloid-associated) proteins which circulate bound to 
high-density lipoproteins. This gives rise to AA proteins, which get deposited in tissues causing 
reactive systemic amyloidosis or secondary amyloidosis. The most common sites are the kidney and heart. It is usually seen secondary to: • Rheumatoid arthritis (most common) • Tuberculosis • Bronchiectasis • Chronic osteomyelitis 317 
Sold by @itachibot • Inflammatory bowel disease • Ankylosing spondylitis • Malignancies - renal cell cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.question: Question 3: What is the most common cause of reactive amyloidosis worldwide?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of reactive amyloidosis worldwide is rheumatoid arthritis. Amyloidosis is reported to occur in 3% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis and is clinically 
significant in one-half of those affected. Conditions associated with reactive systemic (secondary) amyloidosis: • Rheumatoid arthritis (most common) • Ankylosing spondylitis • Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) • Tuberculosis • Bronchiectasis • Chronic osteomyelitis • Malignancies - renal cell cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.question:
Question 4: An elderly woman is brought with worsening memory for the past 3 years. Recently, she has 
been unable to carry out her daily chores and frequently gets lost in the neighborhood. There 
is no history of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. MRI brain shows temporal 
lobe atrophy. Which of the following deposits is likely to be seen in this patient? 311 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. A amyloid deposition is seen in 
this condition. A constitutes the core of cerebral plaques found in Alzheimer's disease. It also gets deposited in 
the walls of cerebral blood vessels. The A protein is derived by proteolysis from a much larger 
transmembrane glycoprotein, called amyloid precursor protein (APP).

questions.question:
Question 5: A diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease has been undergoing hemodialysis for the past 
4 years. Deposition of which of the following is likely in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis as a result of 
the deposition of  2-microglobulin. This protein is present in high concentrations in the serum of persons with renal disease. The 
protein is retained in the circulation because it cannot be filtered through the dialysis membranes. It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in 
the carpal ligament of the wrist, it leads to the development of carpal tunnel syndrome. With new dialysis filters, the incidence of this complication has decreased substantially. 318 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which type of amyloidosis is caused by the mutation of the transthyretin protein?
questions.explanation:
Familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP) is associated with the deposition of mutant 
transthyretin protein (TTR). FAP is an autosomal dominant condition. The deposition occurs as amyloid fibrils in peripheral 
and autonomic nerves. Mutated TTR is prone to misfolding and aggregation, and shows resistance 
to proteolysis. Systemic senile amyloidosis (amyloid of aging) refers to the systemic deposition of normal 
TTR amyloid in elderly patients. Symptomatic patients present with restrictive cardiomyopathy 
and arrhythmias. Another rare form affecting predominantly the heart results from the deposition 
of a mutant form of TTR. Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autosomal-recessive condition seen in individuals of 
Mediterranean descent (Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic). The affected gene encodes a 
protein called pyrin, which is involved in cytokine production. The amyloid fibril proteins in this 
condition are made up of AA proteins. It presents with attacks of fever and serositis. Isolated atrial amyloidosis is associated with AANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) amyloid deposition

questions.question: Question 7: Who among the following patients is at increased risk for developing amyloidosis?

options.a: A patient with maturity-onset diabetes of the young
options.b: A 15-year-old diabetic boy who is on insulin therapy
options.c: A 50-year-old diabetic patient with insulin resistance
options.d: A patient with autosomal dominant non-insulin dependent form of diabetes

questions.explanation:
Older individuals with insulin resistance are likely to have type 2 diabetes mellitus. These patients 
are at increased risk of developing amyloidosis. Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain conditions such as: • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland • Islet tumors of the pancreas • Pheochromocytomas • Undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach • Islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is the most common organ involved in AL amyloidosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common organ involved in AL amyloidosis is renal tissue (Kidneys). They are affected in 70–
80% of patients with amyloidosis. 320 
Sold by @itachibot Heart is the second most commonly affected organ (50–60%), and cardiac involvement is the 
leading cause of death from AL amyloidosis. Renal amyloidosis usually manifests as proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is associated 
with hypoalbuminemia, secondary hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and edema or 
anasarca.

questions.question:
Question 10: A bone marrow examination is being planned for a patient with AL amyloidosis. Which of the 
following is likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Bone marrow examination in AL amyloidosis shows plasmacytosis. The AL type of amyloid or primary amyloidosis is associated with immunocyte dyscrasias like 
multiple myeloma or other B cell neoplasms. The tumor cells in multiple myeloma secrete light 
chains of the immunoglobulins of either the lambda or kappa type, which get deposited in the 
tissues as amyloid. The chemical nature of the amyloid is AL (A for amyloid and L for light chain).

questions.question: Question 11: In lardaceous spleen, deposition of amyloid occurs in which of the following sites?
questions.explanation: Lardaceous spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in sinusoids of the red pulp. Sago spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in splenic follicles (white pulp).

questions.question:
Question 13: In a patient with suspected systemic amyloidosis, which of the following is the initial 
investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
In suspected systemic amyloidosis, the initial investigation of choice is abdominal fat aspirate 
staining. Diagnosis of amyloidosis involves the following: • Localized amyloidosis - biopsy the organ involved. e.g., kidney • Systemic amyloidosis - deposits can be found in any tissue of the body • Initial test - non-invasive test on easily accessible tissue (eg: abdominal fat) which is positive in 
>80% of cases • If this is negative - more invasive biopsies of the kidney, heart, lung or GI tract (rectal biopsy) • Suspected AL amyloidosis - serum and urine electrophoresis and immunoelectrophoresis The histological examination of the biopsy material is the commonest confirmatory method for 
the diagnosis in a suspected case of amyloidosis. The next best step is to determine the type of 
precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and 
biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry. Scintigraphy with radiolabeled serum amyloid P component is a rapid and specific test, which 
gives the extent of the disease. It can be used to follow up on patients undergoing treatment.

questions.question:
Question 14: A kidney biopsy sample is obtained from a patient with high suspicion of amyloidosis. All of 
the following can be used to stain this sample, except:
questions.explanation:
Sudan Black is used for staining lipids, not amyloid. Staining for amyloid: • Congo red - most widely used and specific • Iodine staining - • Used for unfixed specimens or histological sections • Amyloid stains mahogany brown and turns violet on adding sulfuric acid • Thioflavin T and S - • Secondary immunofluorescence with ultraviolet light 322 
Sold by @itachibot • Thioflavin T is useful for demonstrating the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney • Metachromatic stains (crystal violet and methyl violet) - rose-pink appearance. • Periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) positive The image given below shows the amyloid appearance on congo red under plain microscopy.

Question 15: A pathologist is examining a sample from a patient with amyloidosis. Which of the following 
is false about the specimen's appearance?

options.b: Rose pink appearance under crystal violet stain
options.d: Mahogany brown color on iodine staining

questions.explanation:
Amyloid shows apple-green birefringence under polarised microscopy, after staining with Congo 
red. The appearance of amyloid: • Light microscopy - amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance • Congo red stain - the characteristic appearance using this stain is due to the cross- -pleated 
sheet conformation • Under ordinary light, it appears pink or red color (as shown below) 323 
Sold by @itachibot - Under the polarizing microscope - imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits (as 
shown in the image below) • Electron microscopy - continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 
10 nm • X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy - Characteristic cross- -pleated sheet 
conformation. It appears mahogany brown on iodine staining and rose-pink on staining with crystal violet.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not directly involved in graft rejection?
questions.explanation:
Macrophages present foreign graft antigens to the T-cells but are not directly involved in graft 
rejection. 324 
Sold by @itachibot Graft rejection is both humoral and cell-mediated in nature. It is a process in which T-cells and 
antibodies produced against graft antigens react against tissue grafts and destroy it. The major antigenic differences that result in the rejection of transplants are differences in HLA 
alleles. The recipient T-cells are involved in the recognition of the donor MHC molecules and 
mount an immune response. Depending on the antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that are involved 
in T-cell activation, there are 2 pathways: • Direct pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the APCs in the graft • Indirect pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the recipient’s own APCs 
(e.g., macrophages) The early activation of NK cells kill allogeneic target cells directly or via antibody-dependent 
cellular cytotoxicity and release various chemokines and immunomodulatory cytokines.

questions.question:
Question 17: A man is receiving a matched blood group kidney allograft. While closing the abdomen, the 
surgeon notices a sudden color change to pale-white in the transplanted kidney. He decides to 
remove it. Which of the following is responsible for graft rejection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario within minutes of transplant is suggestive of hyperacute rejection and 
is due to preformed antibodies from the recipient.

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient underwent kidney transplantation due to severe diabetic nephropathy. A few 
months later, he presented with fever, malaise, and flank pain. During evaluation, oliguria 
and an acute rise in creatinine levels were observed. A biopsy of the kidney showed 
endotheliitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the biopsy findings of endotheliitis suggest a diagnosis of acute 
cell-mediated graft rejection. In acute cell-mediated graft rejection, CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft cells or CD4+ cells secrete 
cytokines that damage the graft. On histopathology, it produces two different patterns of injury in the graft: • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated 
with focal tubular injury • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III), endotheliitis (swollen 
endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall) Immunosuppressive therapy aims to prevent and reduce acute rejection by blocking the activation 
of alloreactive T cells. In the absence of humoral rejection, patients respond well to 
immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.question:
Question 19: In patients with acute graft-versus-host disease, which of the following organs is least likely to 
be involved?
questions.explanation:
The lung is least likely to get affected in acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into 
immunologically crippled recipients. The transferred cells recognize alloantigens in the host and 
attack host tissues. 325 
Sold by @itachibot It is seen most commonly in the setting of hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation. Rarely, 
it may occur following transplantation of solid organs rich in lymphoid cells (e.g., the liver) or 
transfusion of unirradiated blood. It is of two types, acute and chronic. Acute GVHD develops within days to weeks. There is the involvement of the immune system and 
epithelium of the skin, liver, and intestines. It presents with: • Generalized rash • Jaundice • Bloody diarrhea due to mucosal ulceration • Non-infectious pulmonary infiltrates (rarely), the outcome is generally poor Chronic GVHD may follow the acute syndrome or occur insidiously. It presents with: • Skin - extensive cutaneous injury, with the destruction of skin appendages and dermal fibrosis 
(may resemble systemic sclerosis) • Liver - chronic liver disease, manifested as cholestatic jaundice • GIT - esophageal strictures • Immune system involvement - involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes GVHD is mediated by T lymphocytes contained in the transplanted donor 
cells. Therefore, depletion of donor T cells before transfusion virtually eliminates the disease.

questions.question: Question 20: Graft from identical twin is called:
questions.explanation:
A graft from an identical twin is called an isograft. Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from a donor and is transplanted to a 
recipient who has the same genetic constitution as the donor. For example, graft between identical 
twins. 326 
Sold by @itachibot Microcytic Anemia
